liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Matildas' winning game against Denmark was Australia's most-watched TV broadcast this year, drawing in 3.6 million viewers. It's a program record for the largest television audience for broadcaster Channel Seven and is higher than recent NRL grand finals. Colin Smith, director of global media and sports, which advises sports events on media rights, says it shows how much Australians embrace their local teams. "Like with Ash Barty winning the Australian Open, that Australians actually embrace the leading competitions and especially when their own team, the Matildas, are playing," he told ABC News. "It's very exciting and it doesn't matter whether it's male or female, everyone is really embracing this and it's a really family environment that are following the Matildas." He says the fact the games have been played on home soil is another major factor for ratings success. "It's a combination of being the home World Cup and Australians' embrace of world competitions, and we saw that with the women's Cricket World Cup where we had 85,000 people at the MCG," he says. "They really embraced that and that's increasingly so. "These audience numbers are huge and it's a credit to the Matildas and frankly it's a credit to the organisers having this World Cup here in Australia."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Matildas vs Denmark was the most-watched TV broadcast this year

children.content: The Matildas' winning game against Denmark was Australia's most-watched TV broadcast this year,
drawing in 3.6 million viewers
It's a program record for the largest television audience for broadcaster Channel Seven and is higher than recent NRL grand finals.
Colin Smith,
director of global media and sports, which advises sports events on media rights, says it shows how much Australians embrace their local teams.
"Like with Ash Barty winning the Australian Open, that Australians actually embrace the leading competitions and especially when their own team, the Matildas, are playing," he told ABC News.
"It's very exciting and it doesn't matter whether it's male or female, everyone is really embracing this and it's a really family environment that are following the Matildas."

props.alt: A bald, thin man with glasses in a pink shirt and suit speaks in front of a melbourne city scape background

children.content: (ABC News)
He says the fact the games have been played on home soil is another major factor for ratings success.
"It's a combination of being the home World Cup and Australians' embrace of world competitions, and we saw that with the women's Cricket World Cup where we had 85,000 people at the MCG," he says.
"They really embraced that and that's increasingly so.
"These audience numbers are huge and it's a credit to the Matildas and frankly it's a credit to the organisers having this World Cup here in Australia."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The New South Wales government has lost an appeal against the awarding of $1.5 million to a man wrongly targeted by detectives investigating the disappearance of William Tyrrell. The NSW Court of Criminal Appeal found the maintaining of charges against William "Bill" Spedding was the "worst case" of malicious prosecution proved in NSW. Spedding successfully sued the state for malicious prosecution, wrongful imprisonment, abuse of process and misfeasance in public office. You can keep reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bill Spedding, wrongly targeted over William Tyrrell, will get $1.5m after NSW loses appeal

featuredLink.title: NSW government loses appeal over $1.5m damages awarded to man wrongly targeted by William Tyrrell police

children.content: The New South Wales government has lost an appeal against the awarding of $1.5 million to a man
wrongly targeted by detectives investigating the disappearance of William Tyrrell.
The NSW Court of Criminal Appeal
found the maintaining of charges
against
William "Bill" Spedding
was the "worst case" of malicious prosecution proved in NSW.
Spedding successfully sued the state for
malicious prosecution, wrongful imprisonment, abuse of process and misfeasance in public office.
You can keep reading this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: One of Sydney's most exclusive golf clubs has become a crime scene, after a man's body was found in a pond. Police were called to The Lakes golf club in East Lakes at about 9:30am this morning, after the body was spotted floating in the water. Marine Command has been called in to help retrieve the body and a police helicopter is hovering above the scene taking aerial photos. You can read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A man's body has been found at an exclusive Sydney golf club

featuredLink.title: Body found in pond at exclusive Sydney golf club

Police were called to The Lakes golf club in East Lakes at about 9:30am this morning

Marine Command has been called in to help retrieve the body and a police helicopter is hovering above the scene taking aerial photos.

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA boss Matt Comyn discusses risks to economy

Our senior business correspondent

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Funeral services provider InvoCare has agreed to a lower takeover offer from US private equity firm TPG Global. The lower bid values the funeral service provider at $1.8 billion. TPG tabled an all-cash offer of $12.70 per share, lower than its previous $13 bid for the New South Wales-based company. InvoCare's board unanimously recommended its shareholders to vote in favour of the revised proposal. Shares of Invocare have been on a trading halt since Monday. The deal includes a franked special dividend of up to 60 cents per share that the board said represents total implied value of about $12.96 apiece. Invocare also flagged a challenging macro environment, citing that softer market volumes and inflationary pressures have impacted its margins. The company expects to report earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) for the first half in the range of $61 million to $63 million (compared with A$68.5 million a year ago). TPG, which holds a 19.2% stake in InvoCare, had initially approached the target in March with a $12.65-per-share offer. InvoCare's share price has risen 5.9% to $12.47.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: InvoCare reduces its sale price to $1.8b as takeover talks continue

children.content: Funeral services provider InvoCare has agreed to a lower takeover offer from US private equity firm TPG Global.
The lower bid values the funeral service provider at $1.8 billion.
TPG tabled an all-cash offer of $12.70 per share, lower than its previous $13 bid for the New South Wales-based company.
InvoCare's board unanimously recommended its shareholders to vote in favour of the revised proposal.
Shares of Invocare have been on a trading halt since Monday.
The deal includes a franked special dividend of up to 60 cents per share that the board said represents total implied value of about $12.96 apiece.
Invocare also flagged a challenging macro environment, citing that softer market volumes and inflationary pressures have impacted its margins.

The company expects to report earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) for the first half in the range of $61 million to $63 million (compared with A$68.5 million a year ago).
TPG, which holds a 19.2% stake in InvoCare, had initially approached the target in March with a $12.65-per-share offer.
InvoCare's share price has risen 5.9% to $12.47.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Syrah Resources is the best-performing stock on the ASX 200 today, after its share price jumped 7.8% to 69 cents. This was after the company said it had entered into a deal with South Korea's Samsung SDI — for evaluation of natural graphite active anode supply (from Syrah's Vidalia facility in Louisiana, United States). Natural graphite active anode material is used in manufacturing lithium-ion batteries for electric vehicles, and can be produced at a lower cost with reduced environmental impact. Under the deal, both companies would look to test and qualify active anode material, to finalise, by no later than July 10, 2024. Their intention is to enter a binding offtake agreement for up to 10,000 tonnes per annum, starting from 2026.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shares of miner Syrah Resources jump after signing deal with Samsung
